This introduction is not part of IEEE Std 1522-2004.
IEEE Trial-Use Standard for Testability and Diagnosability Characteristics and Metrics is not part of this introduction.
Systems became more complex costly and difficult to diagnose and repair.
Initiatives were started to address these problems.
The objective of one initiative was to make systems easier to test.
This commercial standard must provide specific unambiguous definitions of criteria for assessing system testability.
IEEE has started initiatives to standardize test architectures.

The IEEE 1232TM Artificial Intelligence Exchange and Service Tie to All Test Environments series of standards provide the foundation for precise and unambiguous testability and diagnosability metrics.

The IEEE 1232TM Artificial Intelligence Exchange and Service Tie to All Test Environments series of standards provide the foundation for precise and unambiguous testability and diagnosability metrics.
It is the objective of this standard to provide notionally correct and inherently useful but mathematically precise definitions of testability measures.
Notionally correct means that the measures are not in conflict with intuitive and historical representations.

IEEE DIAGONOSABLITY CHARACTERISTICS AND METRICS Std 1522-2004 Copyright
All rights reserved.
This subclause provides the definition of each aggregation fundamental to be used in more complex metric definitions.
All fundamental measures are based on the AI-ESTATE common element model and need not be tied to specific diagnostic models (i.e., FTM, DIM, or EDIM).
Within AI-ESTATE, an action is defined by the information model to be “A specific action taken to either test or repair an item.
Actions are the primary entities against which costs are associated.
Ultimately
the diagnosis and repair process is concerned with optimizing the sequence of actions required to return a unit to service.
The function action_set returns the set of all actions within a diagnostic model at a particular level.
FUNCTION action_set (mdl : diagnostic_model; lvl : level) : SET OF action; END_FUNCTION;
Within AI-ESTATE, a diagnosis is defined by the information model to be “a lattice of diagnostic conclusions.
Typically, a diagnosis consists of failures or fault (sic.).
The diagnoses can be interconnected in a lattice to classify constituent units, e.g., by function.
This construct provides a generalized grouping mechanism for the constituents of the unit under test and their failure modes.”
The function diagnosis_set returns the set of all diagnoses within a diagnostic model at a particular level.
FUNCTION diagnosis_set (mdl : diagnostic_model; lvl : level) : SET OF diagnosis; END_FUNCTION;
Within AI-ESTATE, a failure mode is defined by the information model to be “A specific mode or means by which a unit or system can fail.
The specific failure mode is associated, first with the diagnosis, then (by way of the appropriate subtype) to the item that has failed.
The function failure_mode_set returns the set of all failure modes within a diagnostic model at a particular level.

Projected effect of ambiguity on false removals (PEAFR) is a measure of the effect that ambiguous isolation has on the frequency of false removals
PEAFR is described by Equation (10)
AGi is the ith repair item ambiguity group
P(AGi) is the probability of repair item set (AGi)
mdl is the diagnostic model for which this metric is to be calculated
lvl is the level of the diagnostic model at which faults are to be counted
n is the total number of repair item ambiguity groups for the lvl and mdl
PEAFR gives the worst-case percentage of false removals because of diagnostic ambiguity for the specified level of the given diagnostic model
PEAFR projects the relative likelihood of false removals when malfunctions occur
PEAFR is calculated using the formula: PEAFR = (1/n) * Σ(P(AGi) * RT(AGi))
PEAFR is calculated using the formula: PEAFR = (1/n) * Σ(P(AGi) * AGi)
The product life cycle process is related to diagnostic analysis and design.
A comprehensive diagnostic analysis and design program requires a dedicated effort.
The diagnostic design life cycle is organized around five phases.
The five phases are: Requirements definition, Architecture design, Detailed test design, Verification and validation, and Diagnostic maturation.
Each phase is described in a separate section.
Requirements definition is the first step in an effective testability program.
Diagnostic requirements are expressed in performance terms.
Diagnostic requirements express the desired outcome without directing how to achieve it.
Goals are specified for fault detection, fault isolation, and fault isolation resolution.
Mission reliability is a related requirement examined early in the design phase.
Mission reliability measures the prognostic capability of a system to satisfy mission requirements.
Mean time between failure, operational availability, and other metrics may be specified at this time.
Requirements definition is the first step in an effective testability program.
Diagnostic requirements are expressed in performance terms.
Diagnostic requirements express the desired outcome without directing how to achieve it.
Goals are specified for fault detection, fault isolation, and fault isolation resolution.
Diagnostic requirements are typically expressed in performance terms.
Requirements are used to manage diagnostic analysis and development.
Requirements assure that the product will satisfy customer needs and expectations.
Diagnostic requirements are related to fault detection, fault isolation, and fault isolation resolution.
Mission reliability is a related requirement examined early in the design phase.
Mission reliability measures the prognostic capability of a system to satisfy mission requirements.
Mean time between failure, operational availability, and other metrics may be specified at this time.
Requirements are used to manage diagnostic analysis and development.
Mission reliability is a related requirement examined early in the design phase.
Mission reliability measures the prognostic capability of a system to satisfy mission requirements.
Mean time between failure, operational availability, and other metrics may be specified at this time.
Mean time between failure is a system-level metric.
Operational availability is a system-level metric.
Can not duplicate/no evidence of failure rate is a system-level metric.
Mean time between unscheduled maintenance actions is a system-level metric.
Derivative requirements include mean time to repair and maintenance frequency.
Customer warranties may be executed on some metrics.
Customer warranties may be executed on mean time between failure.
Customer warranties may be executed on operational availability.
Customer warranties may be executed on total operating hours.
IEEE Std 1522-2004 is a standard.
The standard is copyrighted by IEEE.
The standard is from 2004.
The standard has annex C.
Annex C is normative.
Annex C contains extensions to the AI-ESTATE standard.
The AI-ESTATE standard is required by the probability_of_diagnosis and probability_of_repair_item_set measures.
The AI-ESTATE standard is defined within IEEE Std 1232-2002.
The AI-ESTATE standard allows a failure rate value to be assigned to each diagnosis.
The AI-ESTATE standard is extended in annex C.
The extension redefines the diagnosis entity in the common element model.
The common element model is defined within IEEE Std 1232-2002.
The AI-ESTATE common element model is used in the extension.
The extension is for the failure rate entity.
The failure rate entity is a subtype of the failure_rate entity.
The failure_rate entity is in the AI-ESTATE common element model.
The failure_rate entity has a subtype called EXTEND_failure_rate.
EXTEND_failure_rate is an abstract entity.
EXTEND_failure_rate is a subtype of the failure_rate entity.
EXTEND_failure_rate contains the frequency value for the associated failure rate.
EXTEND_failure_rate has two subtypes: EXTEND_weibull_failure_rate and EXTEND_exponential_failure_rate.
EXTEND_failure_rate is a subtype of the failure_rate entity.
EXTEND_failure_rate is in the AI-ESTATE common element model.
EXTEND_failure_rate contains the frequency value for the associated failure rate.
EXTEND_failure_rate has a subtype called EXTEND_weibull_failure_rate.
EXTEND_weibull_failure_rate is a subtype of the EXTEND_failure_rate entity.
EXTEND_weibull_failure_rate is used when the associated failure rate is the result of a Weibull distribution.
EXTEND_weibull_failure_rate has two attributes: alpha and beta.
IEEE Std 1522-2004 is a standard for testability and trial-use.
The standard is copyrighted by IEEE.
The standard is from 2005.
The standard has attribute definitions.
The attribute definitions are for the associated_frequency attribute.
The associated_frequency attribute is used to specify the rate of failures associated with a diagnosis.
The associated_frequency attribute is used over a given time span.
EXTEND_weibull_failure_rate is a subtype of the EXTEND_failure_rate entity.
EXTEND_weibull_failure_rate has two attributes: alpha and beta.
beta is a REAL.
beta is an attribute.
alpha is an attribute.
alpha is used to specify the alpha parameter of the Weibull distribution.
beta is used to specify the beta parameter of the Weibull distribution.
EXTEND_exponential_failure_rate is a subtype of EXTEND_failure_rate.
EXTEND_exponential_failure_rate is used when the associated failure rate is the result of an exponential distribution.
EXTEND_exponential_failure_rate is a subtype of EXTEND_failure_rate.
EXTEND_exponential_failure_rate is used when the associated failure rate is the result of an exponential distribution.
EXTEND_diagnosis is a subtype of diagnosis.
EXTEND_diagnosis contains the failure rate for the associated diagnosis.
new_rate is an attribute.
new_rate is used to specify the failure rate associated with the given diagnosis.
